In examining the coast of Portugal near Cascaes <s>some years
ago<\s> I met with several parallel perpendicular
fissures between 10 and 30 feet wide which run NW
from the coast about a mile west of Cascaes
towards the Granite Hills of Cintra through beds
of Limestone and Sandstone of the ages of our Lower
Green Sand. Where these fissures cut through the
cliff they may be well examined & <s>I made<\s> the
following notes were made respecting one of them. The cliff
consisted of thick beds of Sandstone, in which <s>for a fu<\s>
all the minor traces of the bedding are obliterated for a breadth
of two or three feet on each side of the fissure, only the great divisions remaining visible <s>& this
part<\s>
& for about 6 inches on each side of the fissure
the sandstone is laminated, splitting in perpendicular layers
parallel to the walls of the fissure. The crack
itself is filled by vertical layers of sandy Clay
lining each side & a mass of calcareous spar down
the centre. The annexed diagram Fig 6 will
give an idea of the appearance on the cliff.
